Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( g(z) = e^{az} \\), where \\( a \\) is a complex constant. We examine the effect of applying an integral transformation \\( T[f](s) = \\int_0^{\\infty} e^{-st} f(t) \\, dt \\) on \\( g(t) \\) and its implications over the variable \\( s \\).

If an operator \\( L[f](t) = f'(t) + bf(t) \\) (where \\( b \\) is another complex constant) is applied to \\( g(t) \\) after the original transformation \\( T \\), will the new endpoint depend solely on \\( s \\) and not on \\( a \\) or \\( b \\)?
Explanation: Applying the operator \\( L \\) changes the nature and the trajectory of the function. \\( L[g](t) = a e^{at} + b e^{at} = (a+b) e^{at} \\), and then taking \\( T[L[g]](s) \\) would yield \\( \\frac{1}{s-(a+b)} \\), thus showing dependence on both \\( a \\) and \\( b \\), alongside \\( s \\).
